RT @jan_sramek: @ericries Agreed. It would create a lot of value. Have you seen this Eric? The guy works at the Fed actually! https://t.co/‚Ä¶
And there you have it: fully p2p, secure, transparent, ownerless but with stable prices and good macroeconomics. FedCoin
It's not so different from how reserve banking works today. Banks are like nodes, they implement Fed policy in order to get access to $
Why would anyone use FedCoin instead of bitcoin? Because the central bank would accept FedCoins as payment for govt debts & services
(Being the first node to "mine" the new signed policy statement would be equivalent to solving the current hash problem, with same reward)
A central bank could publish its public key and periodically tune the policy of its mining nodes without having to build the infrastructure
Today this is implicit in what software it runs. But it could be made explicit by adding signed policy statements to the blockchain.
Every Bitcoin node effectively subscribes to an economic policy: inflation (how many coins can circulate) and growth (mining difficulty)
I keep meaning to write a blog post about FedCoin- how a central bank could manage a blockchain without many of the problems of Bitcoin.

14/ Kudos to @kir @UrbanitySF @EventDigerati who built this year's program. Thanks to @SarahM who built our original process.
13/ Merit-based selection is harder and more work. This does not only apply to conferences.
12/ If you don't follow this process, and you get a homogeneous result, I don't think you can call your selection meritocratic.
11/ I hope our experience can serve as a model for other conferences to follow. It's not a mystery. There is a real process you can follow.
10/ I'm glad there are activists who have pushed the industry to be more inclusive. They don't get enough credit.
9/ I can't imagine what it must be like for non-white non-male organizers.
8/ Every year, approx one person gets angry about our process and sends me an unfriendly note about it. It's always a white man.
7/ For a lot of our speakers, this is the first time they are sharing their story on stage. New stories = more learning.
6/ Our pipeline has dramatically changed as a result of this process; we get a more diverse (and more interesting) applicant pool.
5/ We don't "lower the bar" for our speakers. In fact, our attendees rate these events as some of the highest-quality they've ever seen.
4/ We don't use quotas.
3/ If you compare the lineups for our first couple years, you can see how far we've come: https://t.co/vl4kpcjumm
2/ First off, this is the fourth year of our merit-based selection process: https://t.co/PV1fyAfBuE

5/ She has built a tremendous team around her, fiercely loyal and deep believers in continuous improvement & innovation.
4/ She is one of the very few executives who is truly ambidextrous: equally effective & articulate in startup and corporate environments.
